document.text: WfiKam Kemper Stanley William Kemper Stanley, 79, of Charleston, S. C., died Saturday in Columbia, 8. C. Born in Appomattox County, he was a son of the late Oden Kemper Stanley and Lettie Herring Stanley, He was retired from the Norfolk Water Works Department. He is survived by two brothers, Guy W. Stanley and Raymond E. Stanley, both of Winchester. Graveside funeral services will be held Thursday at 2 p.m. at Trinity United Methodist Church.

document.text: Thanks. Mr. aud Mrs. Oden Stanley wish to extend, through T he T imes , their heartfelt hanks for the sympathy and kindness of the people of Appo mattox in volunteering help in the hour of their need, resulting from the recent fire at their home. They have set diligently to work to build up again. While gratefully appre ciating the aid voluntarily given to them,gthey wish it to ha known that they art not beggars. Gost or Stoleu. On Thursday last, June 5, a ladys Gold Watch was lost or stoleu from the Farmers Exchange store, where it had been left for repair. Arewaid of 5 will he paid for its return, aud no questions asked about it. 6-11-2 w C. D. SILVEBTHOEN.

document.text: Stonew all. 1 he old year with its joy and sor row has passed into oblivion. Let us not b discouraged with failuies, but strive to reach a higher standard in l.fe and do some good to the unfortunate about us. On the first Christmas day it was Ayr pleasure to attend e Sunday school Xmas tree at Bethel church. There was a large crowd present and everything passed off pleasantly, The church was beautifully decora ted wuh evergreeu und bright aud shining stan. The march was per fect, the singing good anu recitations splendid. The Sar Drill aud Following the Star deserve special mention, Santa was great. The exercises were creditable to all and much enjoyed uy tbe large audience present. On Thursday there was a very pretty Christmas tne at Eiebron, which was much enjoyedtbe con fections were plentiful and tbe mu sic superb. Mr. Robt. Crews of Clifton Forge spent the holidays with his sister, Mrs. J. P. Grow. Abner Grow went back with him and accepted work there. John D. Taylor of Richmond vis ited bis parents Mr. and Mrs. E. M, Taylor Christmas. Lester Sears and his sister Mrs. Marshall were tbe guests of Mrs. W. S- Taylor Christmas. Dr. Whitehead is busy. It is said  bat Miss Mabel Carson, Mrs. Bernard Chick, Miss Lizzi. Thornhill, and two of Mr. Lewis Woodsons children have peumonia. This weather suggests an once of prevention ia worth a pound of cure. Mrs. A. Hickman who bas been very sick for several weeks is report ed better. It is hoped this estima ble lady will soon recover. Mr. and Mrs. Philip Moore of Suffolk who visited his annt Mrs. J. W. Carson Xmas, have returned to tbe city. Mrs. Oden Stauley visited rela tives near Harrisonburg Christmas week. New Years greeting to the T imes and re ders.

document.text: Spout Spring. Your correspondent will have to contribute a few items to remind you that we are s. ill existing. Every body is busy fixing for Christmas. As usual tobacco is being carried to market daily, mostly good prices are realized. Miss Mackie Simms is at home, she closed her school on account of uot having an average. She will teach at the Serene school after Christmas. Mr. Eugene DeMott, of Lynch burg, was tbe guest of bis auut Mrs C. N. Garrett Saturday and Sunday last. Rev. Mr. Sawyer preached at Sa lent for Rev..G. H. Galloway on the first Sunday. Mr. C. N. Garrett expects to move his family to bis home near Ever green uext week. Mr. Oden Stanley, wife and little son, of Lynchburg, are now at the home of bis patents. They will more near Snapps mill soon. Mrs. M. J. Carson has returned from a visit to her daughter Mis. L. L. Adkerson, of Lynchburg. Mr. Ellis Simms beat all the vi cinity on hogs this year so far as we hav- heard. Wishing every body a merry Christmas and a prosperous New Year.

document.text: Oden Resigns Clerkship And Goes To France Washington, D. O.Benja-I min F. Oden, of Appomattox, Va., has resigned as olerk of f the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives to take a position as army field olerk for servioe in France, under the adjutant generals office. He will report for duty on July 21 and will leave shortly afterwards for Franoe. Mr. Odsn, who is above ths draft age, has been feeling for some time that he has kept away from the soene of aotual hostilities about as long as he could. He made up his mind a few days ago to join the field olerioal foroe a n d made a straight application at the War Department for a job without trying to use any politioal pull, whioh he oould easily have ob tained through his eleven years servioe at the Capitol. He reoeived hls appointment, has-been vaccinated for small pox, typhoid fever and other diseases and instructed to re port July 1. He will leave a few days later for New York and then for Franoe. By a strange ooinoidenoe Mr. Oden, who now goes to do bis bit at the front, wrote for the Foreign Affairs Committee the declaration of war whioh was passed by the House and Senate. Mr. Oden has been secretary to Congressman Flood for elev en years, and sinoe six years a g o when th e Democrats came into power in Congress and Mr. Flodd beoame chair man of the Foreign Affairs Committee, has been olerk of the oommittee. Oden gives up his position, which pays 2,600 per year, without any. string tied to it, 8 -do his hit in the way he believes himself best fitted. YlioaeSisiaai clerk of this oommittee, Lester D, Arnold, of Lexington, Va., has also re signed and has enlisted as a yeoman in the navy. Mr. Oden ie the eon-in-law of our townsman, Mr. R. F. Burke.

document.text: Mr. W. E. Moore, of Beck ham, was in town today. Miss Mary 8 weeny, of Lynoh- burg, is a visitor at the home of Mr. H. C. Babcook. It is reported that Mrs. Wm. W right is very ill and her re- qovery uncertain. , Many of our farmers are threshing wheat. The yield will not exceed 60 per cent. Mr. Clem Hanoock went North on a trip Tuesday. in the in terest of C. W. Hanoock  Sons A ruling on the work or fight order only applies to men. of draft age. Mr. and Mrs. J. H. Higgin botham are in Lynohburg at tending the sick bedside of Mr. Higginbothams mother. Prof. Terry Durham,of Camp Jackson, S. C., has arrived safely in Paris, where he takes further training. The school board took a trip toxConcord today to adjust a oounty school matter with Campbell authorities. Mrs. Sallie Flood and friend, Mrs. Sylvester, of Norfolk, paid Appomattox a short visit this week. As a result of a row at Gali lee churoh last week Jim and Lee Watts are spending ten days each in Jail. Miss Louise Gills is able to be out again, after being oonfined in her home with illness for two weeks. The war stamp drive is ovei and Appomattox did her duty, as usual. The official figures will be published as soon as ob- j tainable. Alfalfa and other kinds of hay is-celling for 6 cents per bag of two ounces that is what most brands of smoking tobacco looks and tastes like these days. Mr. Jamie Gills returned Tuesday from Glenlyn, where he occupied a responsible posi tion on a large Government project. Mr. and Mrs. 0. W. Hancock leave tomorrow for a Miohigan hospital, where Mrs. Hanoook will be treated for rheumatism. They will be away for one month. The Local Board has forward ed Questionnaires on to the District Board for classifica tion. This includes new regis trants as well as some reclassi fications. Druggist Chas. F. James has moved into his new quarters in the Atwood Block on the cor- ner. The place is handsomely furnished and his new drug store would be a oredit to a city. Miss Eloise Atwood is expect ed home today from Norfolk, where she has been visiting her sister, Mrs. Edith Palmer. She will bring two guests with her, Miss Elizabeth Oden and Miss Orma Brown. Mr. E. M. Drinkard has re ceived his appointment as game warden of Appomattox county. The appointment is a good one and Mr. Drinkard ex pects the aid of all good citi zens in his efforts to have the game laws enforced. Mrs. Virginia Perry, of Dan ville, a returned missionary from Africa, delivered an in spiring address to a large au dience at Liberty on Sunday night. She was the guest of Rev. and Mrs. McElroy while here. The W. M. U. of the Appo mattox Association closed its session at Rice last Thursday. The reports from the forty-three churches of this district reveal the best years work since the organization. Those from Ap pomattox who took part in the program were Mrs. C. W. Mc Elroy, Mrs. Pitza Gills, Miss Annie Caldwell and Miss Vir ginia Hancock. The following officers were elected for the ensuing year Superintendent, Mrs. C. W. McE roy assistant superintendent, Mrs. W. B. Boureny, Burkeville secretary, Mrs.McCue, Hixburg treasurer, Mrs. Pitza Gills

document.text: Mr. Russell Prilliman, after rusticating in Franxlin county for two weeks, has resumed his duties with Appomattox Hard ware Co. Strayed or stolen from Pur- dum pasture, last Sunday, red cow with white spots, Bhort horns, one noticeably short test. Notify Mrs. J. 0. Hundley, Ap pomattox. Mr. and Mrs.. W. H. Burke and two children and Miss Jo sephine Brown, of Roanoke, and Mr. and Mrs. B. F. Oden are visiting in the home of R. F. Burke this week. Mr. and Mrs. W. F. Wood, Mrs. Jesse Wood, Mrs. Dan Ev ans and Wm. Burke left this a. m. for a visit to relatives in Buckingham and Cumberland counties. Rev. J. C. Leps, who has been in - deolining health for the past two months, is now at The Healing Springe. He was unable to fill his appointment here on last second Sunday. Miss Thelma Phelps, who has been visiting her aunt, Mrs. Harvey Rodgers, returned to her home in Lynchburg Friday, accompanied by her cousin, Miss Bettie Lee Rodgers. Mr. W. E. Smith, wife and son are now busy with they cannery. We predict for this young enterprise a big thing, as it is bound to grow in the hands of these experts. Clean liness and Godliness make .the best of canned goods. Mrs. Julian Abbitt has pur chased of Mrs. Elliott the lot adjoining the Methodist church and will build at once.. The church should have bought this lot long ago, as a building there will greatly circumscribe the church-going people. Miss Gladys Bingham, an Appomattox High School girl is the guest this week of Miss Odelle Woolridge and attend ing the meeting at Liberty church. Miss Bingham has many friends here who always welcome her to our town. Section Foreman Gahliar is visiting his brother-in-law, E R. Primm, in Nottoway this week. Mr. Primm has pur ohased the old R. N. Woolridge estate and will work Mt. View farm for A. H. Clement next year.

document.text: Leesburg, Va. Special. Miss Mary Rogers, who mysteriously disappeared at Saranac Lake, N. Y., last week, was born in this .city about thirty-four years go. She is the daughter of Alexander Rogers. Her mother, before her mar riage to Mr. Rogers, was Miss Julia Clagett, of Leesburg. For many years Miss Rogers was engaged to marry Wil loughby N. Smith, an attorney of Balti more, but would not consent to the marriage during the lifetime of her mother. On account of her mothers age, a large part of the care and man agement of the family estate, Wood- burn, near here, devolved upon Miss Rogers. After her mothers death, in Febru ary, 1903. the estate was sold and Miss Rogers moved to Leesburg, making her home with her sister, Mrs. R. B. Fish- burn. It was not long after this, how ever. that Miss Rogers developed tuber culosis, and upon the advice of her phy sician she went to Saranac Lake, ac companied by a trained nurse and W il loughby N. Smith. She was exception ally popular in this community. At no time while in Leesburg did she appear to suffer from melancholia or any other disease of the mind. Miss Rogers was -not a person of great wealth, as has been generally reported, though she had independent means. The bulk of her property came from a legacy of 10.000 in life insurance left by her , . , . , I brother, Oden Rogers, who died in 1904. government transport which arrived here 1I .g beieved here that she invested this from Nickolieff mutinied, seized their officers and joined the crew of the bat tleship Kniaz Potemkin, to whom they

document.text: Herndon telephone company in Loudoun county that Earman brought with him to Appomattox that brought him to the attention of local leaders. Cashing it at the Bank of Appomattox, he was asked by Richard Floyd Burke, bank president, whether he knew anything about telephones. Mr. Burke asked Earman to go to the telephone office lo cated at the hotel to check on the switch board. He corrected some trouble there with tape and by adding more batteries to the outdated battery operated t system. At this time Mr. Burke asked him to attend a meeting of men planning to organize a telephone company. Officers of that com- ! pany included H.D. Flood, pre sident, Ben Oden, secy, and treasurer Richard F. Burke, vice president with J.B.Abbitt, i and T. E. Smith included on the board of directors. That origi-  nal company was later sold to 1 H.D. Flood and H.C. Pulliam, j Stockholders in the electric plant included C. W. Hancock, j Walter Hancock, S .J. Ferguson, j Earman and others. Mr. Earman had a varied car eer, including work at Oak Rid- j ge Tennessee for the Tennessee j Valley Authority. He was later a tester at Buggs Island Dam, near Clarksville, Va. and had ! a near fatal accident there, j He lived for several years on j Route 460 near Lynchburg and !

document.text: Hanceville, Ala. Special. A tornado passed over Hopewell settlement, one and a half miles north of here, at 2 oclock a. m., and as a result twelve persons are dead, four are fatally injured and a score or more or less seriously hurt, while the destruction to the property is heavy.  he storm came from the southeast and its roar was so terrific that it woke many people, some o whom fled from their houses in time to escape death by having the houses blown down on them Buildings were tossed about like papei boxes and several structures were blown a hundred yards or more. The body of McCoy, who was a prominent farmer, was bfewn 200 yards and landed in i sand pit. The house of Mrs. John Norton was blown down, but the family escaped by crawling under the bed, while the timber and brick fell on top of the bed, breaking the force of the fall. 1 he houses of thc Oden and Griffir families were smashed to splinters, and it seems marvelous that any of their occu pants escaped death. 1 rees were uprooted in all directions and many were blown across the Louis ville and Nashville railroad track, delay ing trains for a time. I he roar of the . storm was heard at Hanceville, where it awoke many neople but no damage was done here. As soor as the destruction wrought became known here rescuers hurried to thc scene to give attention to the dead and wounded.
